instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not entering S4 state <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKERC_EN</SIGNAL> jumping voltage.
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>


liquid damage to io board connector on logic. does not power on. Green light present. No other liquid observable.
Not going into S4 state. Readings:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.6v
PPVIN S5 HS COMPUTING ISNS 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> ISNS 12.58v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5v
(all solid)
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> solid 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> flicking between 0 and 5v

Followed back to <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> pin 4 <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> jumping from 0 -3.3v

Followed back to <CHIP>U8170</CHIP>

<CHIP>U8170</CHIP> pin 4 jumping 0-3.3v
<CHIP>U8170</CHIP> pin 6 (power) solid 3.3v

Following back:

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> jumping 0-3.3v
SMC S4 WAKESRC EN jumping 0-3.3v

Any hints please or is this likely dead PCH ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not entering S4 state <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKERC_EN</SIGNAL> jumping voltage.
threads.message: Power cycling. Is CPU Vcore cycling too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not entering S4 state <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKERC_EN</SIGNAL> jumping voltage.
threads.message: Yes it is <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> jumps from 0 to 1.69v then repeats. A rabbit hole ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not entering S4 state <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKERC_EN</SIGNAL> jumping voltage.
threads.message: There is hope, inspect board carefully for more corrosion. Was the connector cleaned/removed? May still have crap under it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not entering S4 state <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKERC_EN</SIGNAL> jumping voltage.
threads.message:
Thanks Duke. Initially i cleaned and touched up the connector. After this did not change anything i removed the connector entirely. Looking at the pads for the connector they don't look burnt or missing. 
Having another look round the board there is a dab of liquid on top of <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> - but pins and area around look clean - this seems to deal with <SIGNAL>CPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> and is powered by <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> so probably not important if not getting to S4 ? - i may just ultrasonic this and see if that does anything and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not entering S4 state <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKERC_EN</SIGNAL> jumping voltage.
threads.message: I spent a good hour checking over the board but did no spot any hints, as such I did US clean this board. I do now get quarter fan spin which repeats. Same voltage jumping on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>. Any further thoughts before it goes to the bottom of the pile ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not entering S4 state <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKERC_EN</SIGNAL> jumping voltage.
threads.message: Yeah, one drop of water near <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> and it will have fucked the CPU as usual :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not entering S4 state <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKERC_EN</SIGNAL> jumping voltage.
threads.message: Ah, oh well. Thanks for your help it is greatly appreciated.
